Comments: Commonly imaged, and always worth it. The Horsehead shape is dark nebula Barnard 33.

Object: B59, B65, B66, B67 - Pipe Nebula
Comments: The Pipe Nebula is a huge dark nebula that includes Barnard 59, 65, 66, 67, 77, 244, and 256.
The Snake Nebula
Huge SNR spanning about 5°, OIII is prominent in filaments, contrasting nicely with H-alpha.

Object: IC 1318 - Sadr Region - Gamma Cygni Nebula
Comments: Huge nebula around Sadr (Gamma Cygni). Sometimes called the Butterfly Nebula. Split by dark nebula LDN 899.

Beautiful emission nebula with "Elephant's Trunk structure. Clear signal in H-alpha, SII, and OIII. North side features Mu Cephei, the Garnet Star. IC1396 is technically the embedded open cluster. Multiple dark nebulae/Bok globules within.
A top-notch narrowband object with complex structure in H-alpha, SII, and OIII.
A challenging target that requires dark skies.
Chicken Nebula. Dark globules in center known as Thackeray's Globules.
Bright emission nebula with reflection component in center. Emits H-alpha, SII, and OIII.
IC443. Huge and bright SNR with tendrils that make it truly look like a galactic jellyfish.

Type: Ref Neb, Glob CI, Em Neb, Dark Neb
Comments: The greatest variety of bright objects anywhere in the sky. Includes reflection components IC4603, IC4604, M4, the Antares Nebula, faint emission nebulae, and several dark nebulae.
Very bright. OIII and SII in both of the two cores
Usually captured with North America nebula, but a solid target on its own.
Small, but often imaged for good reason. Emission and reflection components, surrounded by dark nebula.
Very large, face-on. Numerous HII regions. Faint outer arms require careful processing.

Object: M11 or NGC 6705 - Wild Duck Cluster
Comments: One of the richest and most compact open clusters.
The Great Hercules Cluster. One of the finest, brightest globulars visible to those in the northern hemisphere.
Beautiful, bright, with H-alpha, OIII, SII. Famous Pillars of Creation Hubble image is of core. M16 is actually the central open cluster; the nebula is Sh2-49 or IC4703.
Also known as Swan Nebula or Checkmark Nebula, bright emission nebula with distinctive shape.
A deep-sky highlight with H-alpha, SII, and OIII present

Object: M22 or NGC 6656 - Great Sagittarius Cluster
Comments: The brightest globular visible to most in the northern hemisphere

One of the top objects in the night sky. Spanning 3° and visible with the naked eye, even short exposures show the basic structure. Longer exposures and careful processing reveal dust lanes, subtle colors, and HII regions.
The Triangulum Galaxy. Low surface brightness can make it surprisingly challenging to process despite its size.
The brightest nebula, and the target for the first deep sky image every taken (Henry Draper, 1880). An easy target with even short exposures. Lots of color, especially pinks and greens.
M45. Bright, wispy reflection nebula complex. Longer exposures rewarded with more detail. Listed in index as separate components (Merope, Electra, etc).
Bright, very dense. Processing can emphasize blue-gold contrast in stars. Nearby bright star is 5 Serpens (mag 5.6).
The Whirlpool Galaxy. Worth imaging year after year. Great structure and color. Interacting companion is NGC5195.
One of the most famous planetary nebulae. Small but bright, excellent for both visual and photographic observation.
The Sunflower Galaxy. Terrific details in the arms, with nice red-blue color contrast due to HII regions.
Includes M65, M66, and NGC 3628. Bright, easy to image. Bright with plenty of detail.
Large, beautiful, and very bright. Looks great in RGB or narrowband Even short exposures reveal wispy tendrils. Contains cluster NGC6530.
Known as Bode's Galaxy, M81 reveals tremendous detail at long focal lengths. Wider fields can capture M82 and/or NGC3077 as well.
Known as the Cigar or Golden Coin Galaxy
Companion to M81, but worth imaging on its own. Pronounced H-alpha around core.

Object: M83 or NGC 5236 - Southern Pinwheel Galaxy
Comments: Very bright barred spiral. Sometimes referred to as the Southern Pinwheel galaxy.
On its own, M86 is an uninteresting elliptical, but it is the center of the famous Markarian's Chain of galaxies at the heart of the Virgo Cluster.
Distinctive planetary nebula with two dark patches giving it an owl-like appearance.
One of the best globular clusters in the sky. Second only to Omega Centauri in brightness, but denser.
A rare ringed galaxy
Small but beautiful combination of blue reflection nebulae with dark dust lanes, and red Herbig-Haro objects.
A deep-sky highlight in RGB color or narrowband. Huge, bright emission nebula with H-alpha, SII, and OIII across a rippled surface.
Very bright emission nebula around Alnitak Usually captured in same field as Horsehead Nebula.
Contains hundreds of cataloged objects, the most prominent of which is the Tarantula Nebula.
Streaks of dust across blue and red reflection components. NGC2170 is a small reflection nebula, surrounded by vdB 67-69 and LBN 999, among other nebula.
Great in RGB, brilliant in narrowband, with strong signals in H-alpha, SII, and OIIL Incredibly photogenic structure, with detail revealed at any focal length.
Beautiful open cluster at the heart of the Rosette Nebula.
Unique complex shape. A great RGB target, but even better in mapped-color narrowband.
A highlight galaxy for more southern imagers. Huge galaxy with detail throughout arms.
It may look like the videogame character through an eyepiece, but imaging reveals terrific details, especially narrowband.
Not as rich in nebulae as the LMC, but frames well with nearby clusters 47 and 75 Tucanae.
Bright target for narrowband or RGB imaging. Dense star field within.

Object: NGC 3603 - Open Cluster & Statue of Liberty Nebula
Comments: Spectacular. Multiple distinct components.
NGC362. Dense little cluster part of widefield with SMC.

Object: NGC 4631 and 4656 - The Whale and Hockey Stick Galaxies
Comments: The Whale Galaxy NGC 4631 (16'x3'), its 'pup' NGC4627, and the Hockey Stick Galaxy, NGC4656 (15'x3') cram a lot of galactic variety into a small space.
Huge, famous galaxy with tremendous dust lane.
Largest and brightest globular in the night sky
Thin, edge-on galaxy. Known as The Splinter Galaxy.
Butterfly shape with dramatic structure in the middle. Known as Fire Bird or Rim Nebula.
Four bright nebula outline the shape of a cat or bear's paw. Strong H-alpha, but no significant OIII or SII.
Has strong OIII and SII components.
Bright, complex. OIII shell can be revealed with enough exposure time.
Known as the Fireworks Galaxy. Very nice face-on galaxy. Near open cluster NGC6939.
Needs little introduction Even short exposures reveal bright red and blue tendrils. 52 Cygni is central star.
Beautiful wisps of red and blue.
Spectacular, bright emission nebula, often imaged with Pelican Nebula next door and LDN935, the dark nebula between them. Dense area corresponding to southern "Mexico" known as the Great Wall.
Beautiful RGB target. While the visible part of the blue reflection nebula is only about 8' across, the surrounding folds of dust span nearly 1°.
Beautiful spiral. Largest of the Deer Lick Group.
Has H-alpha, SII, and OIII signal. Terrific in false-color images. Contains NGC7380.
Great in false color with Ha, SII, and OIII. Dust across core.
Beautiful edge-on spiral with dark dust lane. Clear skies, large optics, and deconvolution reveal fine details in the dust lane.
Emission nebula with reflection and dust components.

Object: Sh2 171 - Teddy Bear nebula in Cefeo
Comments: Some confusion as to which object (Sh2-171/Ced 215 or Ced 214) is NGC7822, arising from Herschel's original description. Either way, they are great narrowband targets. Very wide fields reveal them together as the "Cosmic Question Mark."
Another top narrowband object, frequently imaged together with the Heart Nebula.

Object: Sh2 234 and Sh2-237 - The Spider and the Fly
Comments: Sh2-234 (the "Spider') is a bright, wispy emission nebula that pairs well in an image with Sh2-237 (the "Fly"). SII bright around the core, OIII diffuse throughout. NGC1931 is the cluster embedded within the fly.
More commonly known as IC410. Excellent narrowband target with H-alpha, SII, and OIIL Two "tadpole" structures are prominent in center.
Often imaged with IC443, Sh2-249 has a relatively bright OIII area to the north and several dust lanes that make it a great target in its own right.
Sometimes called the Monkey's Head Nebula. A great mapped-color object, with H-alpha, SII, and OIII emissions

Object: Sh2 273 - The Cone and Fox Fur Nebulae
Comments: Larger area of emission nebulosity with some reflection components. The open cluster within is NGC2264.
Beautiful, complex shape.
Frequently called the Running Man Nebula. Emission and reflection components. Often imaged together with M42.
H-alpha, SII, and OIII make for great mapped-color image. Includes Sh2-292, 296, and 297.
Bright, features prominent pillar structure Great narrowband target. Contains open cluster NGC6823.
